name: f19f6
probTex: Using contour integration (that is, the residue theorem), evaluate\n\[\int_0^\infty\frac{dx}{1+x^2}.\]
solnTex:
First we note that $ rac{1}{1+x^2}$ is an $L^1$ even function, so $\int_0^\infty rac{1}{1+x^2}dx= rac{1}{2}\int_{-\infty}^\infty rac{1}{1+x^2}dx$. Tabling this for now, suppose $R>1$ and let $\gamma_R$ be the rainbow contour in $\mathbb{C}$ given by the straight line $L_R$ from $-R$ to $R$ and the arc $C_R$ from $R$ to $-R$ along the upper half of the circle $|z|=R$, oriented so that $\gamma_R$ has positive orientation. Then
\[\lim_{R	o\infty}\int_{\gamma_R} rac{1}{1+z^2}dz=\lim_{R	o\infty}\int_{L_R} rac{1}{1+z^2}dz+\lim_{R	o\infty}\int_{C_R} rac{1}{1+z^2}dz.\]
We already know that $\lim_{R	o\infty}\int_{L_R} rac{1}{1+z^2}dz=\int_{-\infty}^\infty rac{1}{1+x^2}dx$, we shall show the $C_R$ component vanishes in the limit.
\[\left|\int_{C_R} rac{1}{1+z^2}dzight|\leq\int_{C_R}\left| rac{1}{1+z^2}ight||dz|\leq\int_{C_R} rac{|dz|}{|z^2|-1}=\int_0^\pi rac{Rdt}{R^2-1}= rac{\pi R}{R^2-1}	o0.\]
Therefore $\int_0^\infty rac{1}{1+x^2}dx= rac{1}{2}\lim_{R	o\infty}\int_{\gamma_R} rac{1}{1+z^2}dz$. Moreover, Cauchy's integral theorem tells us that $\int_{\gamma_R} rac{1}{1+z^2}dz$ does not depend on $R$ as long as $R>1$, because the only singularities of $ rac{1}{1+z^2}$ occur at $z=\pm i$. Thus $\int_0^\infty rac{1}{1+x^2}dx= rac{1}{2}\int_{\gamma_R} rac{1}{1+z^2}dz$ for any $R>1$.
Now $ rac{1}{1+z^2}= rac{1}{2i}\left( rac{1}{z-i}- rac{1}{z+i}ight)$, and the residue theorem tells us that the integral of this function around $\gamma_R$ is $2\pi i\left( rac{1}{2i}ight)=\pi$ because the only contributing residue is the $ rac{1}{2i}$ coming from the pole at $z=i$. Therefore $\int_0^\infty rac{1}{1+x^2}dx= rac{\pi}{2}$.
